context: However, this was only observed at the highest ozone level after 51–60min of exposure. A rapid shallow breathing response would decrease TI and increase f, but the opposite was observed. Overall, no firm conclusion could be drawn about effects at the alveolar level, which is considered to apply across species. Although mice are obligate nose breathers and humans oronasal breathers, the potentially higher deposition in the upper airways in the mice compared to humans is expected to be compensated by the higher exposure level.Airway inflammation due to VOCs and limonene/ozone reaction products The BAL fluid analyses did not indicate lung inflammation. In contrast, acute exposure in rats for 3h to a LOP mixture, that was generated from 6ppm limonene and 0.8ppm ozone, showed an up regulation of inflammatory markers (TNF-α, cyclooxygenase-2 and an antioxidant enzyme (superoxide dismutase)) in lung macrophages and type II lung cells, and histopathological changes (Sunil et al., 2007). However, no increase was observed in BAL protein levels and alveolar macrophage counts in contrast to a marginal decrease in isolated type II cells. In a single 4-h exposure of 15 healthy humans, to 50mg/m3 of a mixture of 21 common indoor VOCs neither increased inflammatory cells in nasal lavage fluid nor in the induced sputum; furthermore, the inflammatory biomarkers interleukin-8 (IL-8), leukotriene B4 or albumin did not increase (Pappas et al., 2000).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1-methyl-4-prop-1-en-2-ylcyclohexene is mentioned in relation to airway inflammation caused by volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and their reaction products with ozone. While the study indicates that acute exposure to a mixture containing limonene and ozone resulted in upregulation of inflammatory markers in lung cells, it does not provide direct evidence linking 1-methyl-4-prop-1-en-2-ylcyclohexene specifically to inflammation. The lack of clear association limits the strength of their relationship.
